guide.introduction: Papercrafts at Adafruit! We’re excited to share this Resistor Helper you can download and make yourself. It’s the newest tool in our Circuit Playground family– when you can’t get to your iPhone or iPad, use paper! One side helps you read 4-band types and the other side takes care of 5-band types. The Resistor Helper is on Thingiverse as a PDF (with Illustrator editability preserved). Designed by Adafruit with Matthew Borgatti. You can also grab the PDF on github.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Papercrafts at Adafruit! We’re excited to share this Resistor Helper you can download and make yourself. It’s the newest tool in our Circuit Playground family– when you can’t get to your iPhone or iPad, use paper! One side helps you read 4-band types and the other side takes care of 5-band types. The Resistor Helper is on Thingiverse as a PDF (with Illustrator editability preserved). Designed by Adafruit with Matthew Borgatti. You can also grab the PDF on github.

Relevant parts
  • 4 paper fasteners
Tools
  • Craft knife
  • Cutting mat
  • Ruler
  • Scissors
  • Wire cutters/pliers

lines.text: Print out your Resistor Helper in color. It’s sized to fit on one 8.5″ x 11″ sheet.
lines.text_raw: Print out your Resistor Helper in color. It’s sized to fit on one 8.5″ x 11″ sheet.

lines.text: The wheels are paired with small arrows. Cut around the holder and separate your wheel pairs from each other.
lines.text_raw: The wheels are paired with small arrows. Cut around the holder and separate your wheel pairs from each other.

lines.text: Cut out and glue pairs of colored wheels back to back.
lines.text_raw: Cut out and glue pairs of colored wheels back to back.

lines.text: Liquid glue can make the paper curl a bit, so we recommend drying the wheels under a heavy book (or warm laptop) for about an hour. Or you can use a glue stick!
lines.text_raw: Liquid glue can make the paper curl a bit, so we recommend drying the wheels under a heavy book (or warm laptop) for about an hour. Or you can use a glue stick!

lines.text: Line up your colored wheels by the letters and numbers – 4a is the first wheel on the 4-band side, for example. Keep track of your pieces because we’re about to cut out the ID numbers!
lines.text_raw: Line up your colored wheels by the letters and numbers – 4a is the first wheel on the 4-band side, for example. Keep track of your pieces because we’re about to cut out the ID numbers!

lines.text: Use a craft knife to carefully cut out the viewing windows in the holder.
lines.text_raw: Use a craft knife to carefully cut out the viewing windows in the holder.

lines.text: Double check your windowed holder against your row of wheels so you still remember where they go.
lines.text_raw: Double check your windowed holder against your row of wheels so you still remember where they go.

lines.text: Now carefully cut out the inner circles on your wheels, placing each one back in line before cutting the next one.
lines.text_raw: Now carefully cut out the inner circles on your wheels, placing each one back in line before cutting the next one.

lines.text: Of course you can always refer back to this page if you forget which wheel is which!
lines.text_raw: Of course you can always refer back to this page if you forget which wheel is which!

lines.text: Cut small slits over the red dots on the holder (both sides = 8 cuts). This is where the paper fasteners will anchor each wheel.
lines.text_raw: Cut small slits over the red dots on the holder (both sides = 8 cuts). This is where the paper fasteners will anchor each wheel.

lines.text: Shorten the tabs on four paper fasteners with a pair of clippers.
lines.text_raw: Shorten the tabs on four paper fasteners with a pair of clippers.

lines.text: This is optional but we think it looks nicer!
lines.text_raw: This is optional but we think it looks nicer!

lines.text: Use a ruler to gently score (but not cut!) the fold line on the holder.
lines.text_raw: Use a ruler to gently score (but not cut!) the fold line on the holder.

lines.text: The holder folds easily and neatly after scoring.
lines.text_raw: The holder folds easily and neatly after scoring.

lines.text: Pierce a paper fastener through a tab on one side of the holder and through a wheel.
lines.text_raw: Pierce a paper fastener through a tab on one side of the holder and through a wheel.

lines.text: You can assemble the Resistor Helper with either side as the “front,” but we think you’ll use the 4-band side more often.
lines.text_raw: You can assemble the Resistor Helper with either side as the “front,” but we think you’ll use the 4-band side more often.

lines.text: Pierce through the opposite side of the holder and flare out the tabs on the fastener to secure.
lines.text_raw: Pierce through the opposite side of the holder and flare out the tabs on the fastener to secure.

lines.text: Repeat with the other three wheels.
lines.text_raw: Repeat with the other three wheels.

lines.text: Once you’ve verified you assembled the wheels in the right order, carefully glue together the corners/edges of the holder.
lines.text_raw: Once you’ve verified you assembled the wheels in the right order, carefully glue together the corners/edges of the holder.

lines.text: That’s it! Use and enjoy!
lines.text_raw: That’s it! Use and enjoy!
